trans-unit.source: Protect ARM VMs with Azure Backup | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Protect ARM VMs with Azure Backup | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Protect ARM VMs with Azure Backup service.
trans-unit.target: Protect ARM VMs with Azure Backup service.

trans-unit.source: Use backups of ARM VMs to protect your data.
trans-unit.target: Use backups of ARM VMs to protect your data.

trans-unit.source: Create and register a Recovery Services vault.
trans-unit.target: Create and register a Recovery Services vault.

trans-unit.source: Register VMs, create policy, and protect VMs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Register VMs, create policy, and protect VMs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: First look: Back up ARM VMs to a Recovery Services vault
trans-unit.target: First look: Back up ARM VMs to a Recovery Services vault

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Back up ARM VMs
trans-unit.target: Back up ARM VMs

trans-unit.source: Back up Classic mode VMs
trans-unit.target: Back up Classic mode VMs

trans-unit.source: This tutorial takes you through the set of steps for creating a Recovery Services vault and backing up an Azure virtual machine (VM).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial takes you through the set of steps for creating a Recovery Services vault and backing up an Azure virtual machine (VM).

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is for use with Recovery Services vaults which can be used to protect IaaS v.2 or Azure Resource Manager (ARM)-based VMs.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is for use with Recovery Services vaults which can be used to protect IaaS v.2 or Azure Resource Manager (ARM)-based VMs.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes you already have a VM in your Azure subscription and that you have taken measures to allow the backup service to access the VM.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes you already have a VM in your Azure subscription and that you have taken measures to allow the backup service to access the VM.

trans-unit.source: Azure has two deployment models for creating and working with resources: [Resource Manager and classic](../resource-manager-deployment-model.md).
trans-unit.target: Azure has two deployment models for creating and working with resources: [Resource Manager and classic](../resource-manager-deployment-model.md).

trans-unit.source: This article is for use with Resource Manager and ARM-based VMs.
trans-unit.target: This article is for use with Resource Manager and ARM-based VMs.

trans-unit.source: At a high level, here are the steps that you will complete.
trans-unit.target: At a high level, here are the steps that you will complete.

trans-unit.source: Create a Recovery Services vault for a VM.
trans-unit.target: Create a Recovery Services vault for a VM.

trans-unit.source: Use the Azure portal to select a Scenario, set Policy, and identify items to protect.
trans-unit.target: Use the Azure portal to select a Scenario, set Policy, and identify items to protect.

trans-unit.source: Run the initial backup.
trans-unit.target: Run the initial backup.

trans-unit.source: Step 1 - Create a Recovery Services vault for a VM
trans-unit.target: Step 1 - Create a Recovery Services vault for a VM

trans-unit.source: A Recovery Services vault is an entity that stores all the backups and recovery points that have been created over time.
trans-unit.target: A Recovery Services vault is an entity that stores all the backups and recovery points that have been created over time.

trans-unit.source: The Recovery Services vault also contains the backup policy applied to the protected VMs.
trans-unit.target: The Recovery Services vault also contains the backup policy applied to the protected VMs.

trans-unit.source: Backing up VMs is a local process.
trans-unit.target: Backing up VMs is a local process.

trans-unit.source: You cannot back up VMs from one location to a Recovery Services vault in another location.
trans-unit.target: You cannot back up VMs from one location to a Recovery Services vault in another location.

trans-unit.source: So, for every Azure location that has VMs to be backed up, at least one Recovery Services vault must exist in that location.
trans-unit.target: So, for every Azure location that has VMs to be backed up, at least one Recovery Services vault must exist in that location.

trans-unit.source: To create a Recovery Services vault:
trans-unit.target: To create a Recovery Services vault:

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Azure portal](https://portal.azure.com/)
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Azure portal](https://portal.azure.com/)

trans-unit.source: On the Hub menu, click **Browse** and in the list of resources, type **Recovery Services**.
trans-unit.target: On the Hub menu, click **Browse** and in the list of resources, type **Recovery Services**.

trans-unit.source: As you begin typing, the list will filter based on your input.
trans-unit.target: As you begin typing, the list will filter based on your input.

trans-unit.source: Click **Recovery Services vault**
trans-unit.target: Click **Recovery Services vault**

trans-unit.source: Create Recovery Services Vault step 1
trans-unit.target: Create Recovery Services Vault step 1

trans-unit.source: The list of Recovery Services vaults are displayed.
trans-unit.target: The list of Recovery Services vaults are displayed.

trans-unit.source: On the **Recovery Services vaults** menu, click **Add**
trans-unit.target: On the **Recovery Services vaults** menu, click **Add**

trans-unit.source: Create Recovery Services Vault step 2
trans-unit.target: Create Recovery Services Vault step 2

trans-unit.source: The Recovery Services vault blade opens, prompting you to provide a **Name**, **Subscription**, **Resource group**, and **Location**
trans-unit.target: The Recovery Services vault blade opens, prompting you to provide a **Name**, **Subscription**, **Resource group**, and **Location**

trans-unit.source: Create Recovery Services vault step 5
trans-unit.target: Create Recovery Services vault step 5

trans-unit.source: For **Name**, enter a friendly name to identify the vault.
trans-unit.target: For **Name**, enter a friendly name to identify the vault.

trans-unit.source: The name needs to be unique for the Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: The name needs to be unique for the Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Type a name that contains between 2 and 50 characters.
trans-unit.target: Type a name that contains between 2 and 50 characters.

trans-unit.source: It must start with a letter, and can contain only letters, numbers, and hyphens.
trans-unit.target: It must start with a letter, and can contain only letters, numbers, and hyphens.

trans-unit.source: Click **Subscription** to see the available list of subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Click **Subscription** to see the available list of subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: If you are not sure which subscription to use, use the default (or suggested) subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you are not sure which subscription to use, use the default (or suggested) subscription.

trans-unit.source: There will be multiple choices only if your organizational account is associated with multiple Azure subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: There will be multiple choices only if your organizational account is associated with multiple Azure subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Click **Resource group** to see the available list of Resource groups, or click **New** to create a new Resource group.
trans-unit.target: Click **Resource group** to see the available list of Resource groups, or click **New** to create a new Resource group.

trans-unit.source: For complete information on Resource groups, see [Using the Azure Portal to deploy and manage your Azure resources](../azure-portal/resource-group-portal.md)
trans-unit.target: For complete information on Resource groups, see [Using the Azure Portal to deploy and manage your Azure resources](../azure-portal/resource-group-portal.md)

trans-unit.source: Click **Location** to select the geographic region for the vault.
trans-unit.target: Click **Location** to select the geographic region for the vault.

trans-unit.source: The vault **must** be in the same region as the virtual machines that you want to protect.
trans-unit.target: The vault **must** be in the same region as the virtual machines that you want to protect.

trans-unit.source: If you are unsure of the location in which your VM exists, close out of the vault creation dialog, and go to the list of Virtual Machines in the portal.
trans-unit.target: If you are unsure of the location in which your VM exists, close out of the vault creation dialog, and go to the list of Virtual Machines in the portal.

trans-unit.source: If you have virtual machines in multiple regions, you will need to create a Recovery Services vault in each region.
trans-unit.target: If you have virtual machines in multiple regions, you will need to create a Recovery Services vault in each region.

trans-unit.source: Create the vault in the first location before going to the next location.
trans-unit.target: Create the vault in the first location before going to the next location.

trans-unit.source: There is no need to specify storage accounts to store the backup data--the Recovery Services vault and the Azure Backup service handle this automatically.
trans-unit.target: There is no need to specify storage accounts to store the backup data--the Recovery Services vault and the Azure Backup service handle this automatically.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: It can take a while for the Recovery Services vault to be created.
trans-unit.target: It can take a while for the Recovery Services vault to be created.

trans-unit.source: Monitor the status notifications in the upper right-hand area in the portal.
trans-unit.target: Monitor the status notifications in the upper right-hand area in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Once your vault is created, it opens in the portal.
trans-unit.target: Once your vault is created, it opens in the portal.

trans-unit.source: In your vault, click **All settings** > **Backup Configuration** to view the **Storage replication type**.
trans-unit.target: In your vault, click **All settings** > **Backup Configuration** to view the **Storage replication type**.

trans-unit.source: Choose the storage replication option for your vault.
trans-unit.target: Choose the storage replication option for your vault.

trans-unit.source: List of backup vaults
trans-unit.target: List of backup vaults

trans-unit.source: By default, your vault has geo-redundant storage.
trans-unit.target: By default, your vault has geo-redundant storage.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Azure as a primary backup storage endpoint, it is recommended that you continue using geo-redundant storage.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Azure as a primary backup storage endpoint, it is recommended that you continue using geo-redundant storage.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Azure as non-primary backup storage endpoint, then you can consider choosing locally redundant storage, which will reduce the cost of storing data in Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Azure as non-primary backup storage endpoint, then you can consider choosing locally redundant storage, which will reduce the cost of storing data in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Read more about [geo-redundant](../storage/storage-redundancy.md#geo-redundant-storage) and [locally redundant](../storage/storage-redundancy.md#locally-redundant-storage) storage options in this [overview](../storage/storage-redundancy.md)
trans-unit.target: Read more about [geo-redundant](../storage/storage-redundancy.md#geo-redundant-storage) and [locally redundant](../storage/storage-redundancy.md#locally-redundant-storage) storage options in this [overview](../storage/storage-redundancy.md)

trans-unit.source: After choosing the storage option for your vault, you are ready to associate the VM with the vault.
trans-unit.target: After choosing the storage option for your vault, you are ready to associate the VM with the vault.

trans-unit.source: To begin the association, you should discover and register the Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: To begin the association, you should discover and register the Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Select scenario set policy and define items to protect
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Select scenario set policy and define items to protect

trans-unit.source: Before registering a VM with a vault, run the discovery process to ensure that any new virtual machines that have been added to the subscription are identified.
trans-unit.target: Before registering a VM with a vault, run the discovery process to ensure that any new virtual machines that have been added to the subscription are identified.

trans-unit.source: The process queries Azure for the list of virtual machines in the subscription, along with additional information like the cloud service name and the region.
trans-unit.target: The process queries Azure for the list of virtual machines in the subscription, along with additional information like the cloud service name and the region.

trans-unit.source: If you already have a Recovery Services vault open, proceed to step 2.
trans-unit.target: If you already have a Recovery Services vault open, proceed to step 2.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have a Recovery Services vault open, but are in the Azure portal,
trans-unit.target: If you do not have a Recovery Services vault open, but are in the Azure portal,

trans-unit.source: on the Hub menu, click **Browse**
trans-unit.target: on the Hub menu, click **Browse**

trans-unit.source: In the list of resources, type **Recovery Services**
trans-unit.target: In the list of resources, type **Recovery Services**

trans-unit.source: As you begin typing, the list will filter based on your input.
trans-unit.target: As you begin typing, the list will filter based on your input.

trans-unit.source: When you see **Recovery Services vaults**, click it.
trans-unit.target: When you see **Recovery Services vaults**, click it.

trans-unit.source: Create Recovery Services Vault step 1
trans-unit.target: Create Recovery Services Vault step 1

trans-unit.source: The list of Recovery Services vaults appears.
trans-unit.target: The list of Recovery Services vaults appears.

trans-unit.source: From the list of Recovery Services vaults, select a vault.
trans-unit.target: From the list of Recovery Services vaults, select a vault.

trans-unit.source: The selected vault dashboard opens.
trans-unit.target: The selected vault dashboard opens.

trans-unit.source: Open vault blade
trans-unit.target: Open vault blade

trans-unit.source: From the vault dashboard menu click **Backup** to open the Backup blade.
trans-unit.target: From the vault dashboard menu click **Backup** to open the Backup blade.

trans-unit.source: Open Backup blade
trans-unit.target: Open Backup blade

trans-unit.source: When the blade opens, the Backup service searches for any new VMs in the subscription.
trans-unit.target: When the blade opens, the Backup service searches for any new VMs in the subscription.

trans-unit.source: Discover VMs
trans-unit.target: Discover VMs

trans-unit.source: On the Backup blade, click **Scenario** to open the Scenario blade.
trans-unit.target: On the Backup blade, click **Scenario** to open the Scenario blade.

trans-unit.source: Open Scenario blade
trans-unit.target: Open Scenario blade

trans-unit.source: On the Scenario blade, from the **Backup Type** menu, select **Azure virtual machine backup** and click **OK**
trans-unit.target: On the Scenario blade, from the **Backup Type** menu, select **Azure virtual machine backup** and click **OK**

trans-unit.source: Open Scenario blade
trans-unit.target: Open Scenario blade

trans-unit.source: The Scenario blade closes and the Backup Policy blade opens.
trans-unit.target: The Scenario blade closes and the Backup Policy blade opens.

trans-unit.source: On the Backup blade, select the backup policy you want to apply to the vault and click **OK**
trans-unit.target: On the Backup blade, select the backup policy you want to apply to the vault and click **OK**

trans-unit.source: Select backup policy
trans-unit.target: Select backup policy

trans-unit.source: The default policy is listed in the details.
trans-unit.target: The default policy is listed in the details.

trans-unit.source: If you want to create a new policy, select **Create New**.
trans-unit.target: If you want to create a new policy, select **Create New**.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on defining a backup policy, see [Defining a backup policy](backup-azure-vms-first-look-arm.md#defining-a-backup-policy).
trans-unit.target: For instructions on defining a backup policy, see [Defining a backup policy](backup-azure-vms-first-look-arm.md#defining-a-backup-policy).

trans-unit.source: Once you click OK, the backup policy is associated with the vault.
trans-unit.target: Once you click OK, the backup policy is associated with the vault.

trans-unit.source: Next choose the VMs to associate with the vault.
trans-unit.target: Next choose the VMs to associate with the vault.

trans-unit.source: Choose the virtual machines to associate with the specified policy and click **Select**
trans-unit.target: Choose the virtual machines to associate with the specified policy and click **Select**

trans-unit.source: Select workload
trans-unit.target: Select workload

trans-unit.source: If you do not see the desired VM in the list, click **Refresh**.
trans-unit.target: If you do not see the desired VM in the list, click **Refresh**.

trans-unit.source: If you still do not see the desired VM, check that it exists in the same Azure location as the Recovery Services vault.
trans-unit.target: If you still do not see the desired VM, check that it exists in the same Azure location as the Recovery Services vault.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have defined all settings for the vault, in the Backup blade click **Enable Backup** at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have defined all settings for the vault, in the Backup blade click **Enable Backup** at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: This deploys the policy to the vault and the VMs.
trans-unit.target: This deploys the policy to the vault and the VMs.

trans-unit.source: Enable Backup
trans-unit.target: Enable Backup

trans-unit.source: Step 3 - Initial backup
trans-unit.target: Step 3 - Initial backup

trans-unit.source: Once a backup policy has been deployed on the virtual machine, that does not mean the data has been backed up.
trans-unit.target: Once a backup policy has been deployed on the virtual machine, that does not mean the data has been backed up.

trans-unit.source: By default, the first scheduled backup (as defined in the backup policy) is the initial backup.
trans-unit.target: By default, the first scheduled backup (as defined in the backup policy) is the initial backup.

trans-unit.source: Until the initial backup occurs, the Last Backup Status on the **Backup Jobs** blade shows as **Warning(initial backup pending)**
trans-unit.target: Until the initial backup occurs, the Last Backup Status on the **Backup Jobs** blade shows as **Warning(initial backup pending)**

trans-unit.source: Backup pending
trans-unit.target: Backup pending

trans-unit.source: Unless your initial backup is due to begin very soon, it is recommended that you run **Back up Now**
trans-unit.target: Unless your initial backup is due to begin very soon, it is recommended that you run **Back up Now**

trans-unit.source: To run **Back up Now**:
trans-unit.target: To run **Back up Now**:

trans-unit.source: On the vault dashboard, on the **Backup** tile, click **Azure Virtual Machines**
trans-unit.target: On the vault dashboard, on the **Backup** tile, click **Azure Virtual Machines**

trans-unit.source: Settings icon
trans-unit.target: Settings icon

trans-unit.source: The **Backup Items** blade opens.
trans-unit.target: The **Backup Items** blade opens.

trans-unit.source: On the **Backup Items** blade, right-click the vault you want to back up, and click **Backup now**
trans-unit.target: On the **Backup Items** blade, right-click the vault you want to back up, and click **Backup now**

trans-unit.source: Settings icon
trans-unit.target: Settings icon

trans-unit.source: The Backup job is triggered.
trans-unit.target: The Backup job is triggered.

trans-unit.source: Backup job triggered
trans-unit.target: Backup job triggered

trans-unit.source: To view that your initial backup has completed, on the vault dashboard, on the **Backup Jobs** tile, click **Azure virtual machines**
trans-unit.target: To view that your initial backup has completed, on the vault dashboard, on the **Backup Jobs** tile, click **Azure virtual machines**

trans-unit.source: Backup Jobs tile
trans-unit.target: Backup Jobs tile

trans-unit.source: The Backup Jobs blade opens.
trans-unit.target: The Backup Jobs blade opens.

trans-unit.source: In the Backup jobs blade, you can see the status of all jobs.
trans-unit.target: In the Backup jobs blade, you can see the status of all jobs.

trans-unit.source: Backup Jobs tile
trans-unit.target: Backup Jobs tile

trans-unit.source: As a part of the backup operation, the Azure Backup service issues a command to the backup extension in each virtual machine to flush all writes and take a consistent snapshot.
trans-unit.target: As a part of the backup operation, the Azure Backup service issues a command to the backup extension in each virtual machine to flush all writes and take a consistent snapshot.

trans-unit.source: When the backup job is finished, the status is *Completed*
trans-unit.target: When the backup job is finished, the status is *Completed*

trans-unit.source: Defining a backup policy
trans-unit.target: Defining a backup policy

trans-unit.source: A backup policy defines a matrix of when the data snapshots are taken, and how long those snapshots are retained.
trans-unit.target: A backup policy defines a matrix of when the data snapshots are taken, and how long those snapshots are retained.

trans-unit.source: When defining a policy for backing up a VM, you can trigger a backup job *once a day*.
trans-unit.target: When defining a policy for backing up a VM, you can trigger a backup job *once a day*.

trans-unit.source: When you create a new policy, it is applied to the vault.
trans-unit.target: When you create a new policy, it is applied to the vault.

trans-unit.source: The backup policy interface looks like this:
trans-unit.target: The backup policy interface looks like this:

trans-unit.source: Backup policy
trans-unit.target: Backup policy

trans-unit.source: To create a policy:
trans-unit.target: To create a policy:

trans-unit.source: For **Policy Name** give the Policy a name.
trans-unit.target: For **Policy Name** give the Policy a name.

trans-unit.source: Snapshots of your data can be taken at Daily or Weekly intervals.
trans-unit.target: Snapshots of your data can be taken at Daily or Weekly intervals.

trans-unit.source: Use the **Backup Frequency** drop-down menu to choose whether data snapshots are taken Daily or Weekly.
trans-unit.target: Use the **Backup Frequency** drop-down menu to choose whether data snapshots are taken Daily or Weekly.

trans-unit.source: If you choose a Daily interval, use the highlighted control to select the time of the day for the snapshot.
trans-unit.target: If you choose a Daily interval, use the highlighted control to select the time of the day for the snapshot.

trans-unit.source: To change the hour, de-select the hour, and select the new hour.
trans-unit.target: To change the hour, de-select the hour, and select the new hour.

trans-unit.source: Daily backup policy
trans-unit.target: Daily backup policy

trans-unit.source: If you choose a Weekly interval, use the highlighted controls to select the day(s) of the week, and the time of day to take the snapshot.
trans-unit.target: If you choose a Weekly interval, use the highlighted controls to select the day(s) of the week, and the time of day to take the snapshot.

trans-unit.source: In the day menu, select one or multiple days.
trans-unit.target: In the day menu, select one or multiple days.

trans-unit.source: In the hour menu, select one hour.
trans-unit.target: In the hour menu, select one hour.

trans-unit.source: To change the hour, de-select the selected hour, and select the new hour.
trans-unit.target: To change the hour, de-select the selected hour, and select the new hour.

trans-unit.source: Weekly backup policy
trans-unit.target: Weekly backup policy

trans-unit.source: By default, all **Retention Range** options are selected.
trans-unit.target: By default, all **Retention Range** options are selected.

trans-unit.source: Uncheck any retention range limit you do not want to use.
trans-unit.target: Uncheck any retention range limit you do not want to use.

trans-unit.source: When protecting a VM, a backup job runs once a day.
trans-unit.target: When protecting a VM, a backup job runs once a day.

trans-unit.source: The time when the backup runs is the same for each retention range.
trans-unit.target: The time when the backup runs is the same for each retention range.

trans-unit.source: In the corresponding controls, specify the interval(s) to use.
trans-unit.target: In the corresponding controls, specify the interval(s) to use.

trans-unit.source: Monthly and Yearly retention ranges allow you to specify the snapshots based on a weekly or daily increment.
trans-unit.target: Monthly and Yearly retention ranges allow you to specify the snapshots based on a weekly or daily increment.

trans-unit.source: After setting all options for the policy, at the bottom of the blade click **OK**
trans-unit.target: After setting all options for the policy, at the bottom of the blade click **OK**

trans-unit.source: The new policy is set to be applied to the vault once the Recovery Services vault settings are completed.
trans-unit.target: The new policy is set to be applied to the vault once the Recovery Services vault settings are completed.

trans-unit.source: Return to step 6 of the section, [Select scenario set policy and define items to protect](backup-azure-vms-first-look-arm.md#step-2---select-scenario-set-policy-and-define-items-to-protect)
trans-unit.target: Return to step 6 of the section, [Select scenario set policy and define items to protect](backup-azure-vms-first-look-arm.md#step-2---select-scenario-set-policy-and-define-items-to-protect)

trans-unit.source: Install the VM Agent on the virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Install the VM Agent on the virtual machine

trans-unit.source: This information is provided in case it is needed.
trans-unit.target: This information is provided in case it is needed.

trans-unit.source: The Azure VM Agent must be installed on the Azure virtual machine for the Backup extension to work.
trans-unit.target: The Azure VM Agent must be installed on the Azure virtual machine for the Backup extension to work.

trans-unit.source: However, if your VM was created from the Azure gallery, then the VM Agent is already present on the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: However, if your VM was created from the Azure gallery, then the VM Agent is already present on the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: VMs that are migrated from on-premises datacenters would not have the VM Agent installed.
trans-unit.target: VMs that are migrated from on-premises datacenters would not have the VM Agent installed.

trans-unit.source: In such a case, the VM Agent needs to be installed.
trans-unit.target: In such a case, the VM Agent needs to be installed.

trans-unit.source: If you have problems backing up the Azure VM, check that the Azure VM Agent is correctly installed on the virtual machine (see the table below).
trans-unit.target: If you have problems backing up the Azure VM, check that the Azure VM Agent is correctly installed on the virtual machine (see the table below).

trans-unit.source: If you creating a custom VM, [ensure that the **Install the VM Agent** check box is selected](../virtual-machines/virtual-machines-windows-classic-agents-and-extensions.md) before the virtual machine is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: If you creating a custom VM, [ensure that the **Install the VM Agent** check box is selected](../virtual-machines/virtual-machines-windows-classic-agents-and-extensions.md) before the virtual machine is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: Learn about the [VM Agent](https://go.microsoft.com/fwLink/?LinkID=390493&clcid=0x409) and [how to install it](../virtual-machines/virtual-machines-windows-classic-manage-extensions.md)
trans-unit.target: Learn about the [VM Agent](https://go.microsoft.com/fwLink/?LinkID=390493&clcid=0x409) and [how to install it](../virtual-machines/virtual-machines-windows-classic-manage-extensions.md)

trans-unit.source: The following table provides additional information about the VM Agent for Windows and Linux VMs.
trans-unit.target: The following table provides additional information about the VM Agent for Windows and Linux VMs.

trans-unit.source: Operation
trans-unit.target: Operation

trans-unit.source: Windows
trans-unit.target: Windows

trans-unit.source: Linux
trans-unit.target: Linux

trans-unit.source: Installing the VM Agent
trans-unit.target: Installing the VM Agent

trans-unit.source: Download and install the [agent MSI](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394789&clcid=0x409).
trans-unit.target: Download and install the [agent MSI](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394789&clcid=0x409).

trans-unit.source: You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.
trans-unit.target: You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.

trans-unit.source: [Update the VM property](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx) to indicate that the agent is installed.
trans-unit.target: [Update the VM property](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx) to indicate that the agent is installed.

trans-unit.source: Install the latest [Linux agent](https://github.com/Azure/WALinuxAgent) from GitHub.
trans-unit.target: Install the latest [Linux agent](https://github.com/Azure/WALinuxAgent) from GitHub.

trans-unit.source: You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.
trans-unit.target: You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.

trans-unit.source: [Update the VM property](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx) to indicate that the agent is installed.
trans-unit.target: [Update the VM property](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx) to indicate that the agent is installed.

trans-unit.source: Updating the VM Agent
trans-unit.target: Updating the VM Agent

trans-unit.source: Updating the VM Agent is as simple as reinstalling the [VM Agent binaries](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394789&clcid=0x409)
trans-unit.target: Updating the VM Agent is as simple as reinstalling the [VM Agent binaries](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394789&clcid=0x409)

trans-unit.source: Ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM agent is being updated.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM agent is being updated.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions on [updating the Linux VM Agent ](../virtual-machines-linux-update-agent.md)
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions on [updating the Linux VM Agent ](../virtual-machines-linux-update-agent.md)

trans-unit.source: Ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM Agent is being updated.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM Agent is being updated.

trans-unit.source: Validating the VM Agent installation
trans-unit.target: Validating the VM Agent installation

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the *C:\WindowsAzure\Packages* folder in the Azure VM.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the *C:\WindowsAzure\Packages* folder in the Azure VM.

trans-unit.source: You should find the WaAppAgent.exe file present.
trans-unit.target: You should find the WaAppAgent.exe file present.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the file, go to **Properties**, and then select the **Details** tab.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the file, go to **Properties**, and then select the **Details** tab.

trans-unit.source: The Product Version field should be 2.6.1198.718 or higher.
trans-unit.target: The Product Version field should be 2.6.1198.718 or higher.

trans-unit.source: N/A
trans-unit.target: N/A

trans-unit.source: Backup extension
trans-unit.target: Backup extension

trans-unit.source: Once the VM Agent is installed on the virtual machine, the Azure Backup service installs the backup extension to the VM Agent.
trans-unit.target: Once the VM Agent is installed on the virtual machine, the Azure Backup service installs the backup extension to the VM Agent.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Backup service seamlessly upgrades and patches the backup extension without additional user intervention.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Backup service seamlessly upgrades and patches the backup extension without additional user intervention.

trans-unit.source: The backup extension is installed by the Backup service whether or not the VM is running.
trans-unit.target: The backup extension is installed by the Backup service whether or not the VM is running.

trans-unit.source: A running VM provides the greatest chance of getting an application-consistent recovery point.
trans-unit.target: A running VM provides the greatest chance of getting an application-consistent recovery point.

trans-unit.source: However, the Azure Backup service will continue to back up the VM even if it is turned off, and the extension could not be installed.
trans-unit.target: However, the Azure Backup service will continue to back up the VM even if it is turned off, and the extension could not be installed.

trans-unit.source: This is known as Offline VM.
trans-unit.target: This is known as Offline VM.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the recovery point will be *crash consistent*
trans-unit.target: In this case, the recovery point will be *crash consistent*
